name: King Charles III England Coast Path

ai.summary: The King Charles III England Coast Path is a demanding long-distance coastal hike in the United Kingdom, totaling about 271.4 km along the England Coast Path. It traverses rugged cliffs, sandy coves and exposed headlands with frequently changing weather, making multi-day planning essential.
ai.terrain_summary: Primarily coastal trail with cliff-line paths, surf-washed sections, mud, rocky slabs and occasional beaches. Expect exposed ridges, uneven footing, and variable terrain that can be slippery when wet. Navigation is important in remote sections; tides and sea spray can affect portions of the route.
ai.safety_notes: Distance and isolation: the route is long and may require multi-day trekking with long stretches between towns. Plan for weather variability, strong coastal winds, and rapidly changing conditions. Check tide times for any low-lying sections, carry a detailed map and a GPS device, and inform someone of your plan. Wear sturdy boots with good grip, stay back from cliff edges, and have emergency gear and a contingency plan.
recommended_gear: Sturdy waterproof hiking boots with good ankle support
Waterproof shell jacket and waterproof overpants
Map and compass and/or GPS device
Fully charged phone with offline maps
Water bottles or hydration system plus water treatment (filters or purification tablets)
High-energy snacks and meals; lightweight stove if planning to cook
First aid kit with blister care
Dry bags or waterproof stuff sacks
Gaiters to keep mud and spray out of boots
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly April to October) for milder weather and longer daylight; coastal UK conditions can still be windy and wet, so always check local forecasts and tide charts before starting any coastal segment.
